awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GEM--Global Propagation Characteristics of Electromagnetic Ion Cyclotron Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
The focus of project is to investigate the creation, propagation, and dissipation electromagnetic ion cyclotron waves (EMIC) in the near-Earth space environment.  EMIC waves are created by the interaction of plasma with the Earth's magnetic field.  These waves play an important role in both the energization and loss of particles in the Van Allen radiation belts.  Since the radiation belts overlap the region where satellites operate understanding the factors that can change their intensity is an important aspect of predicting space weather impacts.  This project will use a combination of observations and numerical modeling to address EMIC wave dynamics.  Most previous modeling in this area has used ray-tracing methods.  This project takes the novel approach of using a full wave model to simulate the wave dynamics.   The project will support the efforts of young female scientist who is serving as the PI.  It will also provide support to PhD graduate student.  The investigators will also plan to provide opportunities for undergraduates to participate in the research through partnership with National Undergraduate Fellowship Program in Plasma Physics and Fusion Energy Sciences program.
 
More specifically this project addresses the following questions; (a) How do equatorially generated EMIC waves reach the ground?; (b) How is EMIC wave propagation affected by geomagnetic activity?; and (c) What are the relative contributions of magnetospheric/ionospheric parameters and wave normal angle to EMIC wave propagation from the magnetosphere to the ionosphere? To achieve this goal, the investigators plan to  perform full-wave simulations employing recently developed 2D full-wave code with realistic plasma parameters. We will also analyze recent observations of these waves by Van Allen Probes, THEMIS and GOES satellites and compare them with observations from the ground magnetometer network.

1.     Summary of Project

The goal of this proposal is to investigate wave propagation, and dissipation of Electromagnetic Ion Cyclotron (EMIC) waves in the magnetosphere and ionosphere to address the following questions; (a) How do equatorially generated EMIC waves reach the ground: (a) How do equatorially generated EMIC waves reach the ground?; (b) How is EMIC wave propagation affected by geomagnetic activity?; and (c) What are the relative contributions of magnetospheric/ionospheric parameters and wave normal angle to EMIC wave propagation from the magnetosphere to the ionosphere? To achieve this goal, the team has carried out analysis using spacecraft data and compared them with observations from the ground magnetometer network to characterize wave propagation. The team has coordinated with the lead PI to compare the observational results with full-wave simulation results.

 

2.     Summary of Results

The project explored the observational characteristics of EMIC wave propagation from the source region to the ground using magnetic field data from the Geostationary Operational Environment Satellite (GOES) 13 and Sanikiluaq ground station (SNK) which is magnetically conjugate to the spacecraft. The conjugate data set obtained for approximately 2 years has been statistically compared with the geospace conditions such as solar wind parameters, geomagnetic indices (e.g., Dst, Kp, AE), plasma state in the magnetosphere, and ionospheric conditions (sunlit/dark). The study shows the two statistical groups in which some wave events observed in space did reach the ground ("coincident event") while some waves do not reach the ground ("non-coincident event"). Figure 1 shows examples of a coincident event (top) and a non-coincident event (bottom).

As shown in Figure 2, coincident events are more likely to occur due to strong substorm activity in the magnetosphere (i.e., Kp/AE index). However, the SYM-H, F10.7 indices, and the solar wind dynamic pressure show similar statistics between the coincident and non-coincident groups. This implies that the coincidence of the wave is closely related to certain geomagnetic activity (in particular, substorms) but does not highly depend on all possible triggers that can excite the EMIC wave. In addition, higher-frequency components of the waves can be filtered out during propagation due to solar activity (F10.7) and its ionospheric effect (i.e., conductivity).  

The propagation study has expanded to its interhemispheric behavior with the interhemispheric conjugate magnetometer network between Greenland and Antarctica as well as the MMS spacecraft. A case study has been conducted based on an observation of EMIC waves associated with foreshock transient (FT) events and their ground responses. There are interhemispheric asymmetries in wave propagation, showing difference in spectral power and propagation time as shown in Figure 3. The study concluded that such asymmetries are attributed to the wave generation location associated with a field line configuration (the minimum B pockets off the equator) as shown in Figure 4. 

 

3. Broader Impact

This project supported an early career faculty, the Co-PI of this project. In addition, a postdoctoral fellow (Dr. Sungjun Noh) conducted a large part of the EMIC wave propagation survey. His graduate study was focused mainly on the generation mechnism of EMIC waves in space. Thus, his participation of this study gave him an opportunity to expand his research topic and utilize various data sets. The new results have been published at conferences and in a journal article, which will help foster his career development. 

 

References

Noh, S.-J., Kim, H., Lessard, M., Engebretson, M., Pilipenko, V., Kim, E.-H., et al. (2022). Statistical study of EMIC wave propagation using space-ground conjugate observations. Journal of Geophysical Research: Space Physics, 127, 2022JA030262. https://doi.org/10.1029/2022JA030262

Sung Jun Noh, Hyomin Kim, Dogacan Ozturk, Ilya Kuzichev, Zhonghua Xu, Hui Zhang, Andrew Vu, Terry Liu, James M. Weygand, Michael Hartinger, Xueling Shi, Mark Engebretson, Andrew Gerrard, Eun-Hwa Kim, Marc Lessard, and Christopher Russell, Interhemispheric propagation of ULF waves caused by foreshock transients under quiet solar wind conditions, submitted to Journal of Geophysical Research on April, 2023.
